column1: This great limestone structure, unusually l-shaped rather than rectangular, had seven great doorways and was dedicated to the six major gods – osiris, isis, horus, amun-ra, ra-horakhty and ptah – and also to seti I (1294–1279 bc) himself.
column2: This great limestone structure, unusually L-shaped rather than rectangular, had seven great doorways and was dedicated to the six major gods – Osiris, Isis, Horus, Amun-Ra, Ra-Horakhty and Ptah – and also to Seti I (1294–1279 BC) himself.

column1: Less than 50 years after the end of the amarna 'heresy' – when pharaoh akhenaten broke with tradition by creating a new religion, capital and artistic style – this is a clear attempt to revive the old ways.

column1: As you roam through seti’s dark halls and sanctuaries, an air of mystery surrounds you.

column1: The temple is entered through a largely destroyed pylon and two open courtyards, built by seti I’s son ramses ii, who is depicted on the portico killing Asiatics and worshipping osiris.
column2: The temple is entered through a largely destroyed pylon and two open courtyards, built by Seti I’s son Ramses II, who is depicted on the portico killing Asiatics and worshipping Osiris.

column1: reliefs depict the pharaoh making offerings to the gods and preparing the temple building.

column1: The reliefs here are of the highest quality and hark back to the finest old kingdom work.

column1: Throughout his fascinating life, mark wood has served in the British army, worked in the fire and rescue service and led teams through major polar and mountain expeditions as an explorer.
column2: Throughout his fascinating life, Mark Wood has served in the British Army, worked in the fire and rescue service and led teams through major polar and mountain expeditions as an explorer.

column1: Operating throughout the arctic circle, the himalayas, antarctica and alaska, he has developed a passion for venturing into the frozen, wild regions of the planet.
column2: Operating throughout the Arctic Circle, the Himalayas, Antarctica and Alaska, he has developed a passion for venturing into the frozen, wild regions of the planet.

column1: Having completed over 30 major expeditions around the world, including a solo journey to the south pole followed by a 200-mile solo crossing of the arctic ocean to the north pole, mark’s books solo explorer and rock & ice outline some of his most incredible experiences.
column2: Having completed over 30 major expeditions around the world, including a solo journey to the South Pole followed by a 200-mile solo crossing of the Arctic Ocean to the North Pole, Mark’s books Solo Explorer and Rock & Ice outline some of his most incredible experiences.

column1: The antarctic is one of the last undisturbed places on the planet.

column1: Unlike many other locations where our presence has had a negative impact, antarctica still remains virtually unspoiled.
column2: Unlike many other locations where our presence has had a negative impact, Antarctica still remains virtually unspoiled.

column1: Tourists arrived in antarctica in 1966 when lars-eric lindblad, a Swedish-American entrepreneur and explorer, led the first group onboard a charted argentine naval ship.
column2: Tourists arrived in Antarctica in 1966 when Lars-Eric Lindblad, a Swedish-American entrepreneur and explorer, led the first group onboard a charted Argentine naval ship.

column1: Three years later, he commissioned his own vessel, the ms lindblad explore, and spent the next 20 years taking passengers on educational tours, pioneering what became “expedition cruising”.
column2: Three years later, he commissioned his own vessel, the MS Lindblad Explore, and spent the next 20 years taking passengers on educational tours, pioneering what became “expedition cruising”.

column1: In 1991, the international association of antarctica tour operators (iaato) was established “to advocate and promote the practice of safe and environmentally responsible antarctic travel”.
column2: In 1991, the International Association of Antarctica Tour Operators (IAATO) was established “to advocate and promote the practice of safe and environmentally responsible Antarctic travel”.

column1: iaato works in concert with the antarctic treaty system.
column2: IAATO works in concert with the Antarctic Treaty System.

column1: antarctica is not owned by one nation, but rather governed by this treaty, which was set up to foster scientific investigation.
column2: Antarctica is not owned by one nation, but rather governed by this treaty, which was set up to foster scientific investigation.

column1: It mandates “antarctica shall be used for peaceful purposes only”, all scientific results must be publicly shared, and there shall be no military activity, no nuclear testing, or territorial claims to the land.
column2: It mandates “Antarctica shall be used for peaceful purposes only”, all scientific results must be publicly shared, and there shall be no military activity, no nuclear testing, or territorial claims to the land.

column1: Since the signing of this treaty on december 1, 1959 in washington d.c. by 12 countries, an additional 42 nations have become part of the system.
column2: Since the signing of this treaty on December 1, 1959 in Washington D.C. by 12 countries, an additional 42 nations have become part of the system.

column1: To further guarantee antarctica’s health is retained, the protocol on environmental protection was added to The treaty.
column2: To further guarantee Antarctica’s health is retained, the Protocol on Environmental Protection was added to The Treaty.

column1: While iceland is busy headlining countless travel blogs, design magazines and social media feeds.

column1: Most visitors to Iceland fly into keflavík (the country's international airport) to begin their vacation.
column2: Most visitors to Iceland fly into Keflavík (the country's international airport) to begin their vacation.

column1: Fans of slow travel who are looking for a point of difference, a super-scenic voyage or a means to reduce holiday costs (by bringing their own car or campervan), should consider sailing on smyril line's norröna, the only ferry that cruises from hirtshals in northern denmark to seyðisfjörður in east iceland, via the spectacular faroe islands.
column2: Fans of slow travel who are looking for a point of difference, a super-scenic voyage or a means to reduce holiday costs (by bringing their own car or campervan), should consider sailing on Smyril Line's Norröna, the only ferry that cruises from Hirtshals in northern Denmark to Seyðisfjörður in east Iceland, via the spectacular Faroe Islands.

column1: easy, scenic and an adventure you'll remember, here's why a ferry from denmark is a great way to get to iceland.
column2: Easy, scenic and an adventure you'll remember, here's why a ferry from Denmark is a great way to get to Iceland.

column1: Sailing time is around 36 hours from denmark to the faroe Islands and 19 hours from the faroes to iceland.
column2: Sailing time is around 36 hours from Denmark to the Faroe Islands and 19 hours from the Faroes to Iceland.

column1: The ferry's home port is tórshavn, the capital of the faroe islands, a small archipelago with a population of just 50,000 that's a self-governing country within the kingdom of denmark.
column2: The ferry's home port is Tórshavn, the capital of the Faroe Islands, a small archipelago with a population of just 50,000 that's a self-governing country within the Kingdom of Denmark.

column1: All journeys pause in tórshavn and stopovers range from six hours to three days, depending on the season's schedule.
column2: All journeys pause in Tórshavn and stopovers range from six hours to three days, depending on the season's schedule.

column1: Since the ferry runs weekly, there's also the option of staying a full week or two for a more thorough faroe foray.
column2: Since the ferry runs weekly, there's also the option of staying a full week or two for a more thorough Faroe foray.

column1: Binoculars and cameras at the ready: sail past the shetland islands (part of the uk) en route between denmark and the faroes is a treat, and in clear weather, you'll see distant oil rigs and tankers while sailing the north sea.
column2: Binoculars and cameras at the ready: sail past the Shetland Islands (part of the UK) en route between Denmark and the Faroes is a treat, and in clear weather, you'll see distant oil rigs and tankers while sailing the North Sea.

column1: Arriving into and sailing out of tórshavn is magical.
column2: Arriving into and sailing out of Tórshavn is magical.

column1: As the boat pushes northwest to iceland it travels a relatively narrow passage between the islands of eysturoy and kalsoy, and for two hours the views of emerald peaks will leave you entranced.
column2: As the boat pushes northwest to Iceland it travels a relatively narrow passage between the islands of Eysturoy and Kalsoy, and for two hours the views of emerald peaks will leave you entranced.

column1: Snow-topped peaks and waterfalls welcome you to iceland in dramatic style as the ferry sails 17km up seyðisfjörður to the small, artsy town at the head of the fjord.
column2: Snow-topped peaks and waterfalls welcome you to Iceland in dramatic style as the ferry sails 17km up Seyðisfjörður to the small, artsy town at the head of the fjord.

column1: The norröna is a blend of freight ship, passenger ferry and cruise ship.
column2: The Norröna is a blend of freight ship, passenger ferry and cruise ship.

column1: There are no cooking facilities for passengers on board, but there's a handful of restaurants: the simmer dim steakhouse is upscale (reservations advised), and there are cheaper buffet options and a diner.
column2: There are no cooking facilities for passengers on board, but there's a handful of restaurants: the Simmer Dim Steakhouse is upscale (reservations advised), and there are cheaper buffet options and a diner.

column1: The cafe bars are a good place to while away the hours, especially the sky bar with a view, serving føroya bjór, the beer brewed in the faroes.
column2: The cafe bars are a good place to while away the hours, especially the Sky Bar with a view, serving Føroya Bjór, the beer brewed in the Faroes.

column1: The crowd varies with the seasons, from icelanders and faroe islanders sailing to and from europe for business or pleasure, to holidaymakers treating the summer sailings as a cruise vacation.
column2: The crowd varies with the seasons, from Icelanders and Faroe Islanders sailing to and from Europe for business or pleasure, to holidaymakers treating the summer sailings as a cruise vacation.

column1: plenty of outdoorsy Europeans load up their 4WD camper trailers for full-scale expeditions in Iceland; you'll likely meet motorcyclists and cyclists too, in warmer months.
column2: Plenty of outdoorsy Europeans load up their 4WD camper trailers for full-scale expeditions in Iceland; you'll likely meet motorcyclists and cyclists too, in warmer months.

column2: Tórshavn's charming historical core is Tinganes, a petite peninsula delightfully jumbled with pretty turf-roofed cottages and rustic, red-painted government buildings.

column1: Fans of scandi crime dramas (and ace knitwear) should visit guðrun & guðrun, the tórshavn store from the women who designed that sweater worn by detective sara lund in danish tv drama The killing.
column2: Fans of Scandi crime dramas (and ace knitwear) should visit Guðrun & Guðrun, the Tórshavn store from the women who designed that sweater worn by Detective Sara Lund in Danish TV drama The Killing.

column1: Gourmands should plan a stopover around koks, an acclaimed locavore restaurant 10km south of tórshavn in the pretty hamlet of kirkjubøur.
column2: Gourmands should plan a stopover around Koks, an acclaimed locavore restaurant 10km south of Tórshavn in the pretty hamlet of Kirkjubøur.

column1: In 2017, koks was awarded the faroes' first michelin star.
column2: In 2017, Koks was awarded the Faroes' first Michelin star.

column1: When it's time to explore more of iceland, the 25km road (rte 93) that climbs up and over the mountain pass offers some spectacular vantage points.
column2: When it's time to explore more of Iceland, the 25km road (Rte 93) that climbs up and over the mountain pass offers some spectacular vantage points.

column2: Rte 93 joins the Ring Road (Rte 1, which circumnavigates Iceland) at the hub town of Egilsstaðir.

column1: Buses run year-round between seyðisfjörður and egilsstaðir, and from egilsstaðir northwest to akureyri and on to reykjavík (in summer, buses also run to höfn then along the south coast to reykjavík).

column2: The Norröna operates year-round, on a schedule that varies with season.

column1: The high season covers an 11-week period from mid-June to late august, when prices – and demand – peak (book well ahead); the low season is from mid-September to april.
column2: The high season covers an 11-week period from mid-June to late August, when prices – and demand – peak (book well ahead); the low season is from mid-September to April.

column2: Crocodiles aside, Cuba has little impressive fauna, but the paucity of animals is more than made up for by the abundance of birdlife.

column1: Look out in particular for the colorful tocororo (cuban trogan), the zunzuncito (bee hummingbird), the critically endangered ivory-billed woodpecker and the world's largest flamingo nesting site.
column2: Look out in particular for the colorful tocororo (Cuban trogan), the zunzuncito (bee hummingbird), the critically endangered ivory-billed woodpecker and the world's largest flamingo nesting site.

column1: The gran parque natural montemar is one of many birdwatching highlights.
column2: The Gran Parque Natural Montemar is one of many birdwatching highlights.

column1: An improbable escape from a shipwrecked leisure yacht, handsome bearded guerrillas meting out robin hood–style justice and a classic david versus goliath struggle that was won convincingly by the (extreme) underdogs: cuba's revolutionary war reads like the pages of a barely believable movie script.
column2: An improbable escape from a shipwrecked leisure yacht, handsome bearded guerrillas meting out Robin Hood–style justice and a classic David versus Goliath struggle that was won convincingly by the (extreme) underdogs: Cuba's revolutionary war reads like the pages of a barely believable movie script.

column1: Little has changed in more than 60 years at the disembarkation point of the granma yacht and fidel's wartime hq at mountaintop comandancia de la plata.
column2: Little has changed in more than 60 years at the disembarkation point of the Granma yacht and Fidel's wartime HQ at mountaintop Comandancia de la Plata.

column1: soporific trinidad went to sleep in 1850 and never really woke up.
column2: Soporific Trinidad went to sleep in 1850 and never really woke up.

column1: though it's no secret these days, the time-warped streets still have the power to enchant with their grand colonial homestays, easily accessible countryside and exciting live-music scene.
column2: Though it's no secret these days, the time-warped streets still have the power to enchant with their grand colonial homestays, easily accessible countryside and exciting live-music scene.

column1: But this is also a real working town loaded with all the foibles and fun of 21st-century cuba.
column2: But this is also a real working town loaded with all the foibles and fun of 21st-century Cuba.

column1: Getting lost is a savvy recommendation for any traveler passing through the city of tinajones (clay pots), churches and erstwhile pirates – aka camagüey.
column2: Getting lost is a savvy recommendation for any traveler passing through the city of tinajones (clay pots), churches and erstwhile pirates – aka Camagüey.

column1: Always keen to be different, camagüey was founded on a street grid that deviated from almost every other Spanish colonial city in latin america.
column2: Always keen to be different, Camagüey was founded on a street grid that deviated from almost every other Spanish colonial city in Latin America.

column1: Here the lanes are as labyrinthine as a moroccan medina, hiding Catholic churches, triangular plazas and a growing ensemble of smart boutique hotels encased in restored colonial buildings.
column2: Here the lanes are as labyrinthine as a Moroccan medina, hiding Catholic churches, triangular plazas and a growing ensemble of smart boutique hotels encased in restored colonial buildings.

column1: The brainchild of cuban musician x-alfonso, havana's fábrica de arte cubano has emerged as cuba's finest bona fide art collective, a bastion of creative ideas, loaded with inspiration and excitement.
column2: The brainchild of Cuban musician X-Alfonso, Havana's Fábrica de Arte Cubano has emerged as Cuba's finest bona fide art collective, a bastion of creative ideas, loaded with inspiration and excitement.

column1: With less traffic on the roads than 1940s britain, cuba is ideal for cycling and there's no better place to do it than the bucolic valle de viñales.
column2: With less traffic on the roads than 1940s Britain, Cuba is ideal for cycling and there's no better place to do it than the bucolic Valle de Viñales.

column1: The valley offers all the ingredients of a tropical tour de france: craggy mogotes (limestone monoliths), impossibly green tobacco fields, ambling oxen and spirit-lifting viewpoints at every turn.
column2: The valley offers all the ingredients of a tropical Tour de France: craggy mogotes (limestone monoliths), impossibly green tobacco fields, ambling oxen and spirit-lifting viewpoints at every turn.

column1: Ever since new privatization laws lifted the lid off cuba’s creative pressure cooker in 2011, a culinary revolution has been in full swing.
column2: Ever since new privatization laws lifted the lid off Cuba’s creative pressure cooker in 2011, a culinary revolution has been in full swing.

column1: havana leads the culinary field in number and variety of eating establishments, but there's plenty of regional diversity from caibarién's crabs to baracoa's chocolate.
column2: Havana leads the culinary field in number and variety of eating establishments, but there's plenty of regional diversity from Caibarién's crabs to Baracoa's chocolate.

column1: leave your preconceived notions about cuba at the city limits.
column2: Leave your preconceived notions about Cuba at the city limits.

column1: santa clara is everything you thought this country wasn't – progressive, creative, welcoming to people of all persuasions, enthusiastic about rock 'n' roll, and keen to push the boundaries of art in every direction.
column2: Santa Clara is everything you thought this country wasn't – progressive, creative, welcoming to people of all persuasions, enthusiastic about rock 'n' roll, and keen to push the boundaries of art in every direction.

column1: Youthful energy runs through santa clara like nowhere else in cuba.
column2: Youthful energy runs through Santa Clara like nowhere else in Cuba.

column1: check out the lgbt+ shows at club mejunje, meet arty students at the casa de la ciudad, or wander parque vidal in the evening when the city orchestra is in full swing.

column2: For too long the city of Matanzas has been overlooked by travelers on their way to the all-inclusives of nearby Varadero.

column1: amid the bridges and rivers of this once great cultural city, flickers of its erstwhile beauty are starting to re-emerge in revived classical-music venues, a refurbished theater and a cutting-edge art street decorated with chin-scratching sculptures.
column2: Amid the bridges and rivers of this once great cultural city, flickers of its erstwhile beauty are starting to re-emerge in revived classical-music venues, a refurbished theater and a cutting-edge art street decorated with chin-scratching sculptures.

column1: varadero may have the beaches, but matanzas' gigantic historical legacy will teach you more about the real cuba than 20 repeat visits to the resorts.
column2: Varadero may have the beaches, but Matanzas' gigantic historical legacy will teach you more about the real Cuba than 20 repeat visits to the resorts.

column1: It’s hard to make the wrong choice when you're looking to hike in virginia.
column2: It’s hard to make the wrong choice when you're looking to hike in Virginia.

column1: With over 7,000 miles of ocean and bay views along the coastal plains, more than 50 state and national park or forest sites and more than 550 miles of the Appalachian trail crossing diagonally through the state, virginia earns its reputation as a must-explore state on the east coast.
column2: With over 7,000 miles of ocean and bay views along the coastal plains, more than 50 state and national park or forest sites and more than 550 miles of the Appalachian Trail crossing diagonally through the state, Virginia earns its reputation as a must-explore state on the East Coast.

column1: While virginia’s aforementioned section of the appalachian trail earns a lot of respect from hiking fanatics – hosting nearly a quarter of the thru-hiking trail’s entire length – the wild areas outside of western virginia have trails more than worth your while, whether for a day hike or multi-day camping adventure.
column2: While Virginia’s aforementioned section of the Appalachian Trail earns a lot of respect from hiking fanatics – hosting nearly a quarter of the thru-hiking trail’s entire length – the wild areas outside of western Virginia have trails more than worth your while, whether for a day hike or multi-day camping adventure.

column1: Whether looking in a guidebook or asking a local for recommendations, there’s a strong likelihood old rag mountain comes up.
column2: Whether looking in a guidebook or asking a local for recommendations, there’s a strong likelihood Old Rag Mountain comes up.

column1: Situated in the central-eastern portion of shenandoah national park, this hike is popular, but don’t confuse that with accessibility—consider that this 9.5-mile trail rises more than 2,000 ft in elevation and takes some steep switchback climbing on the way up before you lace up at the trailhead.
column2: Situated in the central-eastern portion of Shenandoah National Park, this hike is popular, but don’t confuse that with accessibility—consider that this 9.5-mile trail rises more than 2,000 ft in elevation and takes some steep switchback climbing on the way up before you lace up at the trailhead.

column1: shoot for a mid-week start earlier in the morning to avoid crowds and cherish the rolling green hills from the peak all by yourself.
column2: Shoot for a mid-week start earlier in the morning to avoid crowds and cherish the rolling green hills from the peak all by yourself.

column1: If you’re coming from the washington, dc region, hiking in virginia doesn’t get any easier than great falls.
column2: If you’re coming from the Washington, DC region, hiking in Virginia doesn’t get any easier than Great Falls.

column1: Just under six miles from the nearest metro stop, this national park service site straddles the potomac river between virginia and maryland and combines the region’s nature and history into one destination.
column2: Just under six miles from the nearest Metro stop, this National Park Service site straddles the Potomac River between Virginia and Maryland and combines the region’s nature and history into one destination.

column1: The park’s best trails have a diverse spread, including family-friendly and accessible paved trails like the old carriage road (1.6 miles one way) and rocky scrambles along riverside cliffs on the billy goat trail (1.75 miles one way).
column2: The park’s best trails have a diverse spread, including family-friendly and accessible paved trails like the Old Carriage Road (1.6 miles one way) and rocky scrambles along riverside cliffs on the Billy Goat Trail (1.75 miles one way).

column1: Hiking here is the status quo for many in the capital beltway region, so park entrance, parking lots and trails can back up early—expect to get to the park close to its 7am opening time, as entrance lines can build up by 10:30am.
column2: Hiking here is the status quo for many in the Capital Beltway region, so park entrance, parking lots and trails can back up early—expect to get to the park close to its 7am opening time, as entrance lines can build up by 10:30am.

column1: stay close to the dc region and you can continue to blend history with a hike on the start of the potomac heritage trail, a national scenic trail stretching through northern virginia, d.c., maryland and pennsylvania.
column2: Stay close to the DC region and you can continue to blend history with a hike on the start of the Potomac Heritage Trail, a National Scenic Trail stretching through northern Virginia, D.C., Maryland and Pennsylvania.

column1: In 1983, the national park service was able to designate a network of existing trails that follow the potomac river as an official national scenic trail, showing off much of the river through the mid-atlantic.
column2: In 1983, the National Park Service was able to designate a network of existing trails that follow the Potomac River as an official National Scenic Trail, showing off much of the river through the Mid-Atlantic.

column1: Most of the trail is cobbled together from existing routes, but if you’re looking for hiking in the virginia portion, consider the 17-mile mount vernon trail near george washington’s homestead south of the district; it’s paved and relatively flat and urban enough to always see the city skyline.
column2: Most of the trail is cobbled together from existing routes, but if you’re looking for hiking in the Virginia portion, consider the 17-mile Mount Vernon Trail near George Washington’s homestead south of the District; it’s paved and relatively flat and urban enough to always see the city skyline.

column1: Settled on the Appalachian trail near the southern end of the state, the hike to mcafee knob offers hikers the chance to check out the thru-hiking trail’s most photographed vista.
column2: Settled on the Appalachian Trail near the southern end of the state, the hike to McAfee Knob offers hikers the chance to check out the thru-hiking trail’s most photographed vista.

column1: It’s hard to believe that a 15,000-acre site easily accessible from the state’s most populous region doesn't dominate more virginia hiking lists, but prince william forest park isn’t like other spots in the state.
column2: It’s hard to believe that a 15,000-acre site easily accessible from the state’s most populous region doesn't dominate more Virginia hiking lists, but Prince William Forest Park isn’t like other spots in the state.

column1: The park on former indigenous doeg land acts as a hub for Washingtonians hoping to get back to nature close to home on a variety of long and short hikes through a piedmont setting.
column2: The park on former Indigenous Doeg land acts as a hub for Washingtonians hoping to get back to nature close to home on a variety of long and short hikes through a Piedmont setting.

column1: The area hosts 37 miles of hiking trails, reachable from the central scenic drive looping through the heart of the park.
column2: The area hosts 37 miles of hiking trails, reachable from the central Scenic Drive looping through the heart of the park.

column1: visit in the fall as the leaves change color and you’ll find a higher number of hikers around, but you're still alone enough to comfortably hike through amber autumn trees.
column2: Visit in the fall as the leaves change color and you’ll find a higher number of hikers around, but you're still alone enough to comfortably hike through amber autumn trees.

column1: chincoteague and assateague islands might be on the farthest eastern reaches of the state, inhabiting the narrow end of the delmarva peninsula, but for hikers in virginia looking for something unique, they’re well worth the trip across the chesapeake bay.
column2: Chincoteague and Assateague Islands might be on the farthest eastern reaches of the state, inhabiting the narrow end of the Delmarva Peninsula, but for hikers in Virginia looking for something unique, they’re well worth the trip across the Chesapeake Bay.

column1: The chincoteague national wildlife refuge shares space on the barrier islands with the assateague island national seashore, offering bay and ocean hikes for all types of hikers interested in a beach getaway.
column2: The Chincoteague National Wildlife Refuge shares space on the barrier islands with the Assateague Island National Seashore, offering bay and ocean hikes for all types of hikers interested in a beach getaway.

column1: hop on the 3-mile wildlife loop to ensure a wildlife encounter as you circle snow goose pool along a paved walkway, or practice your long walks on the beach on the 25-mile beachfront backpacking trail, stretching along the strand of the peninsula up to the virginia-maryland border.
column2: Hop on the 3-mile Wildlife Loop to ensure a wildlife encounter as you circle Snow Goose Pool along a paved walkway, or practice your long walks on the beach on the 25-mile Beachfront Backpacking Trail, stretching along the strand of the peninsula up to the Virginia-Maryland border.

column1: The grayson highlands are the gateway to virginia coming to or going through the southwestern corner of the state, and with the state’s tallest peaks and the start of the Appalachian trail in virginia, are unsurprisingly home to some of the best hiking in the state.
column2: The Grayson Highlands are the gateway to Virginia coming to or going through the Southwestern corner of the state, and with the state’s tallest peaks and the start of the Appalachian Trail in Virginia, are unsurprisingly home to some of the best hiking in the state.

column1: reach the 5,542-ft peak of wilburn ridge and catch sweeping views of the bald hillsides in the neighboring jefferson national forest.
column2: Reach the 5,542-ft peak of Wilburn Ridge and catch sweeping views of the bald hillsides in the neighboring Jefferson National Forest.

column1: While you may avoid crowds in this wild area, you might still not be alone—expect to hear or see in person a few wild ponies from the wilburn ridge hike.
column2: While you may avoid crowds in this wild area, you might still not be alone—expect to hear or see in person a few wild ponies from the Wilburn Ridge hike.

column1: winter in norway’s far north is europe’s premier arctic playground.
column2: Winter in Norway’s Far North is Europe’s premier Arctic playground.

column1: The long arctic night, especially from october to march presents the best chances of seeing them, and they’re usually at their strongest out in rural areas away from the light pollution that rises from cities.
column2: The long Arctic night, especially from October to March presents the best chances of seeing them, and they’re usually at their strongest out in rural areas away from the light pollution that rises from cities.

column1: Sliding across the ice on a sled pulled by dogs could just be the essence of a 21st-century arctic adventure, combining as it does a fine sense of tradition with impeccable eco-friendly credentials.
column2: Sliding across the ice on a sled pulled by dogs could just be the essence of a 21st-century Arctic adventure, combining as it does a fine sense of tradition with impeccable eco-friendly credentials.

column1: Once you leave behind the quiet roads and thinly populated settlements of the north, the otherwise silent trails through boreal forests of pine and spruce can, within seconds, feel like immersion deep in the arctic wilderness.
column2: Once you leave behind the quiet roads and thinly populated settlements of the north, the otherwise silent trails through boreal forests of pine and spruce can, within seconds, feel like immersion deep in the Arctic wilderness.

column1: In karasjok, in the northern Norwegian interior, engholm's husky is run by sven engholm, one of European dog-sledding's most celebrated names, and is highly recommended as your introduction to the world of dog-led exploration.
column2: In Karasjok, in the northern Norwegian interior, Engholm's Husky is run by Sven Engholm, one of European dog-sledding's most celebrated names, and is highly recommended as your introduction to the world of dog-led exploration.

column1: dog-sledding is also possible in alta, tromsø, kirkenes and øvre dividal national park.
column2: Dog-sledding is also possible in Alta, Tromsø, Kirkenes and Øvre Dividal National Park.

column1: No one knows the arctic winter like the indigenous sami, and the opportunity to learn about their traditional lives is one of the main reasons to come here.
column2: No one knows the Arctic winter like the indigenous Sami, and the opportunity to learn about their traditional lives is one of the main reasons to come here.

column1: ravdol reindeer herding in karasjok is a particularly fine initiation.
column2: Ravdol Reindeer Herding in Karasjok is a particularly fine initiation.

column1: reindeer are at the center of sami life, and they live a near-constant migration in search of food – reindeer can locate and eat lichen and moss even buried in deep snow.
column2: Reindeer are at the center of Sami life, and they live a near-constant migration in search of food – reindeer can locate and eat lichen and moss even buried in deep snow.

column1: Spending time with them as they move with the herds and fashion a comfortable existence in the harshest of winter conditions is a life lesson of a very arctic kind.
column2: Spending time with them as they move with the herds and fashion a comfortable existence in the harshest of winter conditions is a life lesson of a very Arctic kind.

column1: whichever way you do it, racing through an ice-bound forest or across a frozen lake has a vaguely addictive quality.
column2: Whichever way you do it, racing through an ice-bound forest or across a frozen lake has a vaguely addictive quality.

column1: It may not be Norway’s most eco-friendly way of getting around, but most excursions don’t last long and do provide an essential taste of arctic life.
column2: It may not be Norway’s most eco-friendly way of getting around, but most excursions don’t last long and do provide an essential taste of Arctic life.

column1: Snowmobiling is possible across norway’s north, including around alta and tromsø, but kirkenes, almost as far as you can go in Arctic norway without falling into russia, is especially good; the pasvik valley, a thin sliver of Norwegian territory, is especially beautiful in winter and barents safari is an excellent kirkenes-based operator.
column2: Snowmobiling is possible across Norway’s north, including around Alta and Tromsø, but Kirkenes, almost as far as you can go in Arctic Norway without falling into Russia, is especially good; the Pasvik Valley, a thin sliver of Norwegian territory, is especially beautiful in winter and Barents Safari is an excellent Kirkenes-based operator.

column1: Perhaps the strangest of all winter pursuits in northern norway, king crab safaris take place in fjord waters close to kirkenes.
column2: Perhaps the strangest of all winter pursuits in northern Norway, king crab safaris take place in fjord waters close to Kirkenes.

column1: introduced into the area from their native north pacific by russian scientists in 1961, the king crab has proven hugely successful – tens of millions now inhabit the Barents sea.
column2: Introduced into the area from their native North Pacific by Russian scientists in 1961, the king crab has proven hugely successful – tens of millions now inhabit the Barents Sea.

column1: safaris take you out onto the water in an inflatable zodiac and dressed in arctic-strength clothing (provided as part of your safari), but don’t worry – it’s a professional diver who plunges beneath the icy waters to find the crabs, emerging from the depths in a struggle of limbs, both crab and human.
column2: Safaris take you out onto the water in an inflatable Zodiac and dressed in Arctic-strength clothing (provided as part of your safari), but don’t worry – it’s a professional diver who plunges beneath the icy waters to find the crabs, emerging from the depths in a struggle of limbs, both crab and human.

column1: The beds are blocks of ice, as is the rather stylish bar area, while arctic-strength sleeping bags keep you warm at night – overnight temperatures in the rooms sit at an otherwise uncomfortable minus-four to minus-seven degrees celsius.
column2: The beds are blocks of ice, as is the rather stylish bar area, while Arctic-strength sleeping bags keep you warm at night – overnight temperatures in the rooms sit at an otherwise uncomfortable minus-four to minus-seven degrees Celsius.

column1: Two options stand out – the kirkenes snow hotel and alta’s sorrisniva igloo hotel.
column2: Two options stand out – the Kirkenes Snow Hotel and Alta’s Sorrisniva Igloo Hotel.

column1: oslo is norway’s most important international airport, with onward connections to northern cities such as tromsø, alta and kirkenes.
column2: Oslo is Norway’s most important international airport, with onward connections to northern cities such as Tromsø, Alta and Kirkenes.

column1: A private vehicle is best for getting around, but the hurtigruten coastal ferry connects tromsø and kirkenes.
column2: A private vehicle is best for getting around, but the Hurtigruten coastal ferry connects Tromsø and Kirkenes.

column1: For general norway information, check out visit norway, while northern norway focuses on the country’s north.
column2: For general Norway information, check out Visit Norway, while Northern Norway focuses on the country’s north.

column1: havana's main cemetery (a national monument), one of the largest in the Americas, is renowned for its striking religious iconography and elaborate marble statues.
column2: Havana's main cemetery (a national monument), one of the largest in the Americas, is renowned for its striking religious iconography and elaborate marble statues.

column1: far from being eerie, a walk through these 57 hallowed hectares can be an educational and emotional stroll through the annals of cuban history.
column2: Far from being eerie, a walk through these 57 hallowed hectares can be an educational and emotional stroll through the annals of Cuban history.

column1: A map (cuc$1) showing the graves of assorted artists, sportspeople, politicians, writers, scientists and revolutionaries is for sale at the entrance.
column2: A map (CUC$1) showing the graves of assorted artists, sportspeople, politicians, writers, scientists and revolutionaries is for sale at the entrance.

column1: enter via the splendid byzantine-romanesque gateway, the puerta de la paz; the tomb of independence leader general máximo gómez (1905) is on the right (look for the bronze face in a circular medallion).
column2: Enter via the splendid Byzantine-Romanesque gateway, the Puerta de la Paz; the tomb of independence leader General Máximo Gómez (1905) is on the right (look for the bronze face in a circular medallion).

column1: Further along past the first circle, and also on the right, are the firefighters monument (1890) and the neo-Romanesque capilla central (1886), in the center of the cemetery.
column2: Further along past the first circle, and also on the right, are the firefighters monument (1890) and the neo-Romanesque Capilla Central (1886), in the center of the cemetery.

column1: Just northeast of the chapel is the graveyard's most celebrated (and visited) tomb, that of señora amelia goyri, better known as la milagrosa (the miraculous one), who died while giving birth on may 3, 1901.
column2: Just northeast of the chapel is the graveyard's most celebrated (and visited) tomb, that of Señora Amelia Goyri, better known as La Milagrosa (the Miraculous One), who died while giving birth on May 3, 1901.

column1: When the bodies were exhumed some years later, amelia's body was uncorrupted (a sign of sanctity in the catholic faith), and the baby, who had been buried at its mother's feet, was allegedly found in her arms.
column2: When the bodies were exhumed some years later, Amelia's body was uncorrupted (a sign of sanctity in the Catholic faith), and the baby, who had been buried at its mother's feet, was allegedly found in her arms.

column1: As a result, la milagrosa became the focus of a huge spiritual cult in cuba, and thousands of people come here annually with gifts, in the hope of fulfilling dreams or solving problems.
column2: As a result, La Milagrosa became the focus of a huge spiritual cult in Cuba, and thousands of people come here annually with gifts, in the hope of fulfilling dreams or solving problems.

column1: As important as la milagrosa among the santería community, the 'tomb of hermano josé' marks the grave of a woman called leocadia pérez herrero, a black havana medium known for her great acts of charity among the poor in the early 20th century.
column2: As important as La Milagrosa among the Santería community, the 'tomb of Hermano José' marks the grave of a woman called Leocadia Pérez Herrero, a black Havana medium known for her great acts of charity among the poor in the early 20th century.

column1: leocadia said that she consulted with a santería priest called hermano josé who encouraged and guided her in her generous acts.
column2: Leocadia said that she consulted with a Santería priest called Hermano José who encouraged and guided her in her generous acts.

column1: As a spiritual and superstitious person, she always kept a painting of hermano josé's image in her house, and when she died in 1962 the canvas was buried alongside her.
column2: As a spiritual and superstitious person, she always kept a painting of Hermano José's image in her house, and when she died in 1962 the canvas was buried alongside her.

column2: Located on the finger of land jutting into the Bay of Fundy, this 13km-return trail from Scots Bay, taking around five hours, is one of the most popular hikes in Nova Scotia, with little elevation change through a tunnel of forest.

column1: The hike ends in a dramatic, often windy clearing on cliffs high above the bay of fundy where seabirds nest.
column2: The hike ends in a dramatic, often windy clearing on cliffs high above the Bay of Fundy where seabirds nest.

column1: wander down to the rocky outcrop at the vertiginous end of the trail to see the tides creating waves called tidal rips that flow through a cluster of rock pinnacles.
column2: Wander down to the rocky outcrop at the vertiginous end of the trail to see the tides creating waves called tidal rips that flow through a cluster of rock pinnacles.

column1: Take time before or after the hike to look for agates along the beach at scots bay.
column2: Take time before or after the hike to look for agates along the beach at Scots Bay.

column1: Aside from the lake louise shoreline, no place in banff sees as much foot traffic as the wide, paved johnston canyon trail.
column2: Aside from the Lake Louise shoreline, no place in Banff sees as much foot traffic as the wide, paved Johnston Canyon Trail.

column1: More intrepid hikers can climb to the inkpots, colorful natural pools in a high mountain valley.
column2: More intrepid hikers can climb to the Inkpots, colorful natural pools in a high mountain valley.

column1: Where the temperate rainforest comes down to kiss the ocean, the citizens of ucluelet have built a magnificent 10km (6.2mi) trail that can be equally spectacular in both the sun and (stormy) rain.
column2: Where the temperate rainforest comes down to kiss the ocean, the citizens of Ucluelet have built a magnificent 10km (6.2mi) trail that can be equally spectacular in both the sun and (stormy) rain.

column1: It starts with a 2.6km-loop (1.6mi) that winds past a 1915 amphitrite lighthouse and progresses northwest as far as the Ancient cedars loop and the rocky bluffs beyond.
column2: It starts with a 2.6km-loop (1.6mi) that winds past a 1915 Amphitrite lighthouse and progresses northwest as far as the Ancient Cedars loop and the Rocky Bluffs beyond.

column1: pack your easel.
column2: Pack your easel.

column1: For 900km (559mi), the bruce trail winds along the top of the niagara escarpment, from the queenston heights park on the niagara peninsula to the tobermory harbor on the bruce peninsula.
column2: For 900km (559mi), the Bruce Trail winds along the top of the Niagara Escarpment, from the Queenston Heights Park on the Niagara Peninsula to the Tobermory harbor on the Bruce Peninsula.

column1: day hikes along the trail are an appealing way to spend a sunny afternoon.
column2: Day hikes along the trail are an appealing way to spend a sunny afternoon.

column1: From its origin near the junction of hwy 540 and bidwell rd (25km/15.5mi southwest of Little current) this 9km-trail (6mi) on the niagara escarpment on manitoulin island, with its 2km (1.2mi) of dramatic 70m (230ft) cliffs, leads to the highest point on the island (351m) with breathtaking views of the crinkled shoreline along the north channel.
column2: From its origin near the junction of Hwy 540 and Bidwell Rd (25km/15.5mi southwest of Little Current) this 9km-trail (6mi) on the Niagara Escarpment on Manitoulin Island, with its 2km (1.2mi) of dramatic 70m (230ft) cliffs, leads to the highest point on the island (351m) with breathtaking views of the crinkled shoreline along the North Channel.

column1: As winemaking in neighboring napa valley grows ever more upscale, here sun-dappled vineyards are still surrounded by pastoral ranchlands.
column2: As winemaking in neighboring Napa Valley grows ever more upscale, here sun-dappled vineyards are still surrounded by pastoral ranchlands.

column1: relax and enjoy a late-harvest zinfandel with a scoop of white-chocolate ice cream drizzled with organic olive oil.
column2: Relax and enjoy a late-harvest zinfandel with a scoop of white-chocolate ice cream drizzled with organic olive oil.

column1: Take a shortcut back on the 500m (1640ft) Adventure trail, which involves descending on rickety wood ladders and clambering up, over and down massive boulders.
column2: Take a shortcut back on the 500m (1640ft) Adventure Trail, which involves descending on rickety wood ladders and clambering up, over and down massive boulders.

column1: The trailhead for this easy 2½-hour round-trip hike into gorgeous kinney lake (4.5km one-way) is 3km (1.86mi) north of the mt robson visitor centre.
column2: The trailhead for this easy 2½-hour round-trip hike into gorgeous Kinney Lake (4.5km one-way) is 3km (1.86mi) north of the Mt Robson Visitor Centre.

column2: A longer hike carries on from Kinney Lake to Berg Lake (23km/14mi each way), with seven camping areas along the way.

column2: All Berg Lake hikers must check into Mt Robson Visitor Centre before heading out.

column2: In summer, Sutton is prime hiking territory, especially in this conservation area, where 80km of trails have been carved through the thickly forested mountains.

column2: Meditate on eternity at Muir Woods National Monument, Humboldt Redwoods State Park or Redwood National & State Parks.

column1: Called the pacific coast highway farther south, locals in northern california simply call the 400-mile stretch from san francisco to crescent city “highway 1.” small communities punctuate the coast as the highway alternates between hairpin switchbacks and straight stretches through pastoral farmland.

column2: In Fort Bragg, stop and admire the “glass beach”; admire the lumber baron’s old Victorians in Eureka while relishing in its current artistic community, or pause to admire the lighthouses that stand as silent guardians of the continent's confluence of land and sea.

column2: Meander through wildflower-strewn meadows in valleys carved by glaciers, avalanches and earthquakes.

column2: Sunny Santa Monica grants instant happiness: learn to surf, ride a solar-powered Ferris wheel, dance under the stars on an old-fashioned pier, show kids the aquarium’s tidal touch pools or just dip your toes in the water and let your troubles float away.

column1: From a distance, california’s largest state park at first looks like a desolate expanse of some 640,000 acres, but if you’re lucky enough to visit in the spring, it comes to life like no place else as wildflowers burst across the hillsides in great swathes of color.
column2: From a distance, California’s largest state park at first looks like a desolate expanse of some 640,000 acres, but if you’re lucky enough to visit in the spring, it comes to life like no place else as wildflowers burst across the hillsides in great swathes of color.

column1: beautiful balboa park is where san diegans come to play –  when they’re not at the beach.
column2: Beautiful Balboa Park is where San Diegans come to play –  when they’re not at the beach.

column1: Across the park, immerse the whole family in more than a dozen art, cultural and science museums, marvel at the Spanish colonial and mission revival-style architecture while sunning yourself along el prado promenade, or nab tickets for a show at the old globe theaters, modeled on the famous shakespearean original.
column2: Across the park, immerse the whole family in more than a dozen art, cultural and science museums, marvel at the Spanish colonial and mission revival-style architecture while sunning yourself along El Prado promenade, or nab tickets for a show at the Old Globe Theaters, modeled on the famous Shakespearean original.

column1: Rising suddenly from the surrounding flatlands, there’s no other pile of rock in california that stirs the imagination quite like mt shasta.
column2: Rising suddenly from the surrounding flatlands, there’s no other pile of rock in California that stirs the imagination quite like Mt Shasta.

column1: john muir said its beauty made his “blood turn to wine.” And a late-19th-century explorer reported that survivors of a lost continent were living in tunnels below its surface.
column2: John Muir said its beauty made his “blood turn to wine.” And a late-19th-century explorer reported that survivors of a lost continent were living in tunnels below its surface.

column2: If you road-trip along the coast between San Diego and Sonoma, you'll be following in the footsteps of early Spanish conquistadors and Catholic priests.

column1: foremost among them was franciscan friar junípero serra, who founded many of california’s 21 original missions in the late 18th century.
column2: Foremost among them was Franciscan friar Junípero Serra, who founded many of California’s 21 original missions in the late 18th century.

column2: Some missions, such as San Juan Capistrano, have been authentically restored, with flowering gardens, stone arcades, fountains, and chapels adorned by spiritual frescoes.

column1: While most travelers in san francisco stay west, there’s plenty happening in the east bay to justify the bart or ferry fare.
column2: While most travelers in San Francisco stay west, there’s plenty happening in the East Bay to justify the BART or ferry fare.

column2: Often foggy and wind-tossed, the peninsular fishing village of Monterey calls to mind John Steinbeck and his gritty novels of American realism.

column2: Hop aboard a whale-watching cruise out into the bay's national marine sanctuary, some of whose aquatic denizens also swim in Cannery Row’s eco-conscious, family-friendly aquarium.

column2: Speed over the curved bay bridge or board the ferry from San Diego to seaside Coronado, a civilized escape back to a more genteel era.

column2: In northern San Diego County, Legoland California is worth a day or two for Lego-themed rides and learning opportunities and an entire “Miniland” of world monuments built of the plastic bricks.

column1: And if you have a just a few hours (or a few bucks) to spare, the amusement parks of the santa monica pier and san diego’s belmont park are historic, hometown throwbacks.
column2: And if you have a just a few hours (or a few bucks) to spare, the amusement parks of the Santa Monica Pier and San Diego’s Belmont Park are historic, hometown throwbacks.

column1: If one park could encapsulate northern california, point reyes would get our vote.
column2: If one park could encapsulate Northern California, Point Reyes would get our vote.

column1: Step across the san andreas fault, then stand out by the lighthouse at what feels like land’s end and peer through binoculars at migratory whales.
column2: Step across the San Andreas fault, then stand out by the lighthouse at what feels like land’s end and peer through binoculars at migratory whales.

column1: witness the raucous antics of a seasonal colony of giant elephant seals at chimney rock or hike among free-ranging herds of hulking tule elk.
column2: Witness the raucous antics of a seasonal colony of giant elephant seals at Chimney Rock or hike among free-ranging herds of hulking tule elk.

column1: In orange county, huntington beach draws the hang-loose surfer crowd, while yachties play in the fantasyland of newport beach.

column1: But further south, laguna beach beckons, with its sophisticated blend of money, culture and natural beauty.
column2: But further south, Laguna Beach beckons, with its sophisticated blend of money, culture and natural beauty.

column1: laguna’s bohemian past still peeks out in downtown’s art galleries, adorable arts-and-crafts bungalows tucked beside multimillion-dollar mansions and the annual festival of arts and dramatic pageant of the masters.
column2: Laguna’s bohemian past still peeks out in downtown’s art galleries, adorable arts-and-crafts bungalows tucked beside multimillion-dollar mansions and the annual Festival of Arts and dramatic Pageant of the Masters.
