column1: But further south, laguna beach beckons, with its sophisticated blend of money, culture and natural beauty.
column2: But further south, Laguna Beach beckons, with its sophisticated blend of money, culture and natural beauty.

column1: Tossed like so many lost pearls off the coast, the channel islands are california's last outpost of civilization.
column2: Tossed like so many lost pearls off the coast, the Channel Islands are California's last outpost of civilization.

column1: They’ve been that way for thousands of years, ever since seafaring chumash tribespeople established villages on these remote rocks.
column2: They’ve been that way for thousands of years, ever since seafaring Chumash tribespeople established villages on these remote rocks.

column1: get back to nature in channel islands national park, a wildlife haven with fantastic sea kayaking and snorkeling, or make a posh getaway to mediterranean-esque catalina island, with its harborfront hotels.
column2: Get back to nature in Channel Islands National Park, a wildlife haven with fantastic sea kayaking and snorkeling, or make a posh getaway to Mediterranean-esque Catalina Island, with its harborfront hotels.

column1: Two deserts – the colorado from the south and the mojave from the north – meet northeast of palm springs to create joshua tree national park.
column2: Two deserts – the Colorado from the south and the Mojave from the north – meet northeast of Palm Springs to create Joshua Tree National Park.

column1: Nestled among the mountains, streams and oases are the namesake joshua trees, with splayed limbs crowned with fronds.
column2: Nestled among the mountains, streams and oases are the namesake Joshua trees, with splayed limbs crowned with fronds.

column1: camp out in the park, or stay, play and eat to the north in funky little towns like joshua tree with its art and folk music scene and pioneertown, originally an old west movie set and now headlined by a hipster honky-tonk.
column2: Camp out in the park, or stay, play and eat to the north in funky little towns like Joshua Tree with its art and folk music scene and Pioneertown, originally an old west movie set and now headlined by a hipster honky-tonk.

column1: mendocino is the north coast’s salt-washed sandcastle of dreams.
column2: Mendocino is the North Coast’s salt-washed sandcastle of dreams.

column1: Originally a 19th-century port built by new englanders, mendo today belongs to bohemians who favor art and nature.
column2: Originally a 19th-century port built by New Englanders, Mendo today belongs to bohemians who favor art and nature.

column1: For many visitors, sri lanka is all about blissful, blonde beaches, but another world awaits in the rugged, mountainous interior.
column2: For many visitors, Sri Lanka is all about blissful, blonde beaches, but another world awaits in the rugged, mountainous interior.

column1: With sri lanka's manageable scale – the island measures just 268 miles long by 139 miles wide – there are few complicated logistics for hikers to worry about.
column2: With Sri Lanka's manageable scale – the island measures just 268 miles long by 139 miles wide – there are few complicated logistics for hikers to worry about.

column1: Known variously as adam’s peak (the spot where adam first set foot on earth after being cast out of heaven), sri pada (the ‘sacred footprint’ left by the buddha as he headed towards paradise) and samanalakande (butterfly mountain, where butterflies go to die), sri lanka’s most sacred summit is revered by Buddhists, hindus, muslims and Christians alike.
column2: Known variously as Adam’s Peak (the spot where Adam first set foot on earth after being cast out of heaven), Sri Pada (the ‘sacred footprint’ left by the Buddha as he headed towards paradise) and Samanalakande (Butterfly Mountain, where butterflies go to die), Sri Lanka’s most sacred summit is revered by Buddhists, Hindus, Muslims and Christians alike.

column1: The dawn hike up the 5,200 steps leading from the village of dalhousie to the mountaintop is as much a spiritual journey as a physical expedition, offering a window onto sri lanka’s soul as well as views over its jaw-dropping landscapes.
column2: The dawn hike up the 5,200 steps leading from the village of Dalhousie to the mountaintop is as much a spiritual journey as a physical expedition, offering a window onto Sri Lanka’s soul as well as views over its jaw-dropping landscapes.

column1: Most undertake the strenuous hike during the pilgrimage season, which begins on the poya (full moon) day in december and runs until the vesak festival in may.
column2: Most undertake the strenuous hike during the pilgrimage season, which begins on the poya (full moon) day in December and runs until the Vesak festival in May.

column1: pilgrims start walking at 2am to reach the summit before dawn, but you can begin the climb from dalhousie soon after night falls to beat the crowds, who slow progress to a snail’s pace on poya days.
column2: Pilgrims start walking at 2am to reach the summit before dawn, but you can begin the climb from Dalhousie soon after night falls to beat the crowds, who slow progress to a snail’s pace on poya days.

column1: At the summit, catch your breath as you watch the dawn sun illuminate sri lanka like a blessing, then pay your respects at the rock footprint left by the buddha, shiva or adam (depending on which legend you subscribe to).
column2: At the summit, catch your breath as you watch the dawn sun illuminate Sri Lanka like a blessing, then pay your respects at the rock footprint left by the Buddha, Shiva or Adam (depending on which legend you subscribe to).

column1: It’s easy to fill several days wandering to lookouts and posing for pics (or watching instagrammers do the posing) beside the landmark nine arches bridge.
column2: It’s easy to fill several days wandering to lookouts and posing for pics (or watching Instagrammers do the posing) beside the landmark Nine Arches Bridge.

column1: start your explorations with the 4.5km round trip to little adam’s peak – a green knoll with great views of waterfalls and tea factories shimmering out of the mist that cloaks the surrounding hills.
column2: Start your explorations with the 4.5km round trip to Little Adam’s Peak – a green knoll with great views of waterfalls and tea factories shimmering out of the mist that cloaks the surrounding hills.

column1: The 10km walk to ella rock is more demanding, but also more rewarding; a sustained climb through classic highland country, starting right on the railway tracks at ella station.
column2: The 10km walk to Ella Rock is more demanding, but also more rewarding; a sustained climb through classic highland country, starting right on the railway tracks at Ella Station.

column1: The largest lowland rainforest in the country, sinharaja forest reserve is a biodiverse wonderland, framed by rivers and buzzing with forest wildlife, including rare mammals and 147 bird species, including 33 species found only in sri lanka.
column2: The largest lowland rainforest in the country, Sinharaja Forest Reserve is a biodiverse wonderland, framed by rivers and buzzing with forest wildlife, including rare mammals and 147 bird species, including 33 species found only in Sri Lanka.

column1: Entry to sinharaja is on foot not by jeep, with a mandatory guide to keep you safe in the dense and damp undergrowth.
column2: Entry to Sinharaja is on foot not by jeep, with a mandatory guide to keep you safe in the dense and damp undergrowth.

column1: Most hikers base themselves in the villages of deniyaya or kudawa, where you can purchase entry tickets and arrange a trek with the guides hanging around the park gates.
column2: Most hikers base themselves in the villages of Deniyaya or Kudawa, where you can purchase entry tickets and arrange a trek with the guides hanging around the park gates.

column1: stay nearby to access the park early in the morning when the trails are quiet and the wildlife is most active, before the tour groups arrive from the coast.
column2: Stay nearby to access the park early in the morning when the trails are quiet and the wildlife is most active, before the tour groups arrive from the coast.

column1: The sinharaja rain forest view villas at deniyaya is a lovely jungle escape that won’t burn too big a hole in your holiday budget.
column2: The Sinharaja Rain Forest View Villas at Deniyaya is a lovely jungle escape that won’t burn too big a hole in your holiday budget.

column1: okay, it’s not a trek in the classic sense, but there’s plenty of tramping required to gain the summit of sri lanka’s most famous lookout, crowned by the ruins of King kasyapa’s palace.
column2: Okay, it’s not a trek in the classic sense, but there’s plenty of tramping required to gain the summit of Sri Lanka’s most famous lookout, crowned by the ruins of King Kasyapa’s palace.

column1: The reward for all this exertion is a view over an endless sweep of sri lankan countryside extending to the horizon in all directions – just watch out for the bothersome wasps on the way up!
column2: The reward for all this exertion is a view over an endless sweep of Sri Lankan countryside extending to the horizon in all directions – just watch out for the bothersome wasps on the way up!

column1: For views with more privacy, walk for about a kilometer to reach the 5th-century monastic complex at pidurangula, crowning another rocky outcrop to the north of sigiriya.
column2: For views with more privacy, walk for about a kilometer to reach the 5th-century monastic complex at Pidurangula, crowning another rocky outcrop to the north of Sigiriya.

column1: It’s a half-hour clamber past ancient buddhist temples and carvings to the summit, which looks out over a carpet of forest with the mighty mass of sigiriya rising like a stone exclamation mark in the middle of the vista.
column2: It’s a half-hour clamber past ancient Buddhist temples and carvings to the summit, which looks out over a carpet of forest with the mighty mass of Sigiriya rising like a stone exclamation mark in the middle of the vista.

column1: come with your own transport and you can add on a slender loris-spotting night walk with the resident naturalist at the jetwing vil uyana hotel near kimbissa.
column2: Come with your own transport and you can add on a slender loris-spotting night walk with the resident naturalist at the Jetwing Vil Uyana hotel near Kimbissa.

column1: In sri lanka, world’s end is the apt nickname for the sheer drop-off at the edge of the horton plains, which looks out over one of sri lanka's most jaw-dropping vistas.
column2: In Sri Lanka, World’s End is the apt nickname for the sheer drop-off at the edge of the Horton Plains, which looks out over one of Sri Lanka's most jaw-dropping vistas.

column1: horton plains national park is one of the few reserves where visitors can walk unaccompanied, but there’s no public transport, so you’ll need to arrange a drop-off and pick-up in nuwara eliya or ohiya.
column2: Horton Plains National Park is one of the few reserves where visitors can walk unaccompanied, but there’s no public transport, so you’ll need to arrange a drop-off and pick-up in Nuwara Eliya or Ohiya.

column1: After a 4km hike across the plateau, the terrain drops away without warning at world’s end.
column2: After a 4km hike across the plateau, the terrain drops away without warning at World’s End.

column1: The trail loops back to pretty baker’s falls before returning to the national park entrance at far inn, so you’ll need about three hours to complete the 9.5km round trip.
column2: The trail loops back to pretty Baker’s Falls before returning to the national park entrance at Far Inn, so you’ll need about three hours to complete the 9.5km round trip.

column1: – of sri lanka's tea country, head to the town of haputale, floating in a sea of tea gardens in the middle of the island.
column2: – of Sri Lanka's tea country, head to the town of Haputale, floating in a sea of tea gardens in the middle of the island.

column1: The tea estate at dambatenne was founded in 1890 by thomas lipton, whose name still appears on teabags served at breakfast all over the globe, and the lookout is known as lipton’s seat, where he came to survey the plantations.
column2: The tea estate at Dambatenne was founded in 1890 by Thomas Lipton, whose name still appears on teabags served at breakfast all over the globe, and the lookout is known as Lipton’s Seat, where he came to survey the plantations.

column1: history aside, the viewpoint makes a fine day walk from haputale, and you can combine the trip with a tour of the still-working dambatenne tea factory to see the tea-making process.
column2: History aside, the viewpoint makes a fine day walk from Haputale, and you can combine the trip with a tour of the still-working Dambatenne Tea Factory to see the tea-making process.

column1: In practice, most visitors do the trip in reverse, taking a bus or tuk-tuk to lipton’s seat to arrive early in the morning when the views are clearest, and then strolling downhill through the tea gardens to reach the factory.
column2: In practice, most visitors do the trip in reverse, taking a bus or tuk-tuk to Lipton’s Seat to arrive early in the morning when the views are clearest, and then strolling downhill through the tea gardens to reach the factory.

column1: To trek off the tourist map in sri lanka, head to the densely forested knuckles range northeast of kandy.
column2: To trek off the tourist map in Sri Lanka, head to the densely forested Knuckles Range northeast of Kandy.

column1: This rugged massif forms part of the Unesco-listed peak wilderness protected area, founded to protect the island’s threatened montane and cloud forests.
column2: This rugged massif forms part of the Unesco-listed Peak Wilderness Protected Area, founded to protect the island’s threatened montane and cloud forests.

column1: Hiking in the knuckles range, you’ll see more locals than tourists, and probably more buffaloes, monkeys and birds than people.
column2: Hiking in the Knuckles Range, you’ll see more locals than tourists, and probably more buffaloes, monkeys and birds than people.

column1: guides are mandatory though, so you’ll need to make arrangements with an agency in kandy.
column2: Guides are mandatory though, so you’ll need to make arrangements with an agency in Kandy.

column1: The name 'knuckles' comes from the profile of these craggy peaks, which resemble a closed fist from a distance.
column2: The name 'Knuckles' comes from the profile of these craggy peaks, which resemble a closed fist from a distance.

column1: Most people visit on two-day camping treks from kandy, exploring the small villages and terraced paddy fields in the foothills before climbing onto the high massif.
column2: Most people visit on two-day camping treks from Kandy, exploring the small villages and terraced paddy fields in the foothills before climbing onto the high massif.

column1: bring a bird book – close encounters with many of the 128 bird species that inhabit the park are pretty much guaranteed.
column2: Bring a bird book – close encounters with many of the 128 bird species that inhabit the park are pretty much guaranteed.

column1: lace up your hiking boots and get ready to hit the trails!
column2: Lace up your hiking boots and get ready to hit the trails!

column1: The vast wilderness of rocky mountain national park is a natural playground for fans of all things adventurous.
column2: The vast wilderness of Rocky Mountain National Park is a natural playground for fans of all things adventurous.

column1: The terrain in rocky mountain national park is vital and elemental.
column2: The terrain in Rocky Mountain National Park is vital and elemental.

column1: pine forest cloaks the lower elevations, giving way to windswept tundra that provides a unique ecosystem for hundreds of species of wildflowers.
column2: Pine forest cloaks the lower elevations, giving way to windswept tundra that provides a unique ecosystem for hundreds of species of wildflowers.

column1: above, sculpted peaks silhouetted against the blue sky serve as a dramatic reminder of the last ice age.
column2: Above, sculpted peaks silhouetted against the blue sky serve as a dramatic reminder of the last ice age.

column1: It’s a big place, so to help you find your way, here are some of the best hikes in rocky mountain national park.
column2: It’s a big place, so to help you find your way, here are some of the best hikes in Rocky Mountain National Park.

column1: bear lake is one of the park’s most popular destinations for first-time visitors, with good reason.
column2: Bear Lake is one of the park’s most popular destinations for first-time visitors, with good reason.

column1: On this trail, you’ll have front-row seats for a view of the dramatic glacial valleys and hulking granite summits that make the Rocky mountains such a singular landscape.
column2: On this trail, you’ll have front-row seats for a view of the dramatic glacial valleys and hulking granite summits that make the Rocky Mountains such a singular landscape.

column1: The bear lake loop is a short and easy hike that's perfect for families or people with limited mobility.
column2: The Bear Lake Loop is a short and easy hike that's perfect for families or people with limited mobility.

column1: Several longer and more strenuous paths set off from the bear lake trailhead or nearby glacier gorge trailhead, including hikes to alberta falls (1.8 miles round trip), mills lake (5.6 miles) and the loch (6.2 miles), which can be extended to the exquisite lake of glass and sky pond (9.8 miles) – as serene as their names suggest.
column2: Several longer and more strenuous paths set off from the Bear Lake trailhead or nearby Glacier Gorge trailhead, including hikes to Alberta Falls (1.8 miles round trip), Mills Lake (5.6 miles) and the Loch (6.2 miles), which can be extended to the exquisite Lake of Glass and Sky Pond (9.8 miles) – as serene as their names suggest.

column1: While flattop mountain (12,324ft, 8.8 miles) may not be the park’s best summit, there’s no denying its magnetic pull from down below.
column2: While Flattop Mountain (12,324ft, 8.8 miles) may not be the park’s best summit, there’s no denying its magnetic pull from down below.

column1: use the park shuttles to get to the trailhead.
column2: Use the park shuttles to get to the trailhead.

column1: You can’t miss lake helene, which sits serenely beneath the imposing, rough-cut cliffs of notchtop and flattop mountains.
column2: You can’t miss Lake Helene, which sits serenely beneath the imposing, rough-cut cliffs of Notchtop and Flattop mountains.

column1: To do this hike, park at fern lake trailhead (the endpoint), and then take the shuttle to bear lake trailhead.
column2: To do this hike, park at Fern Lake Trailhead (the endpoint), and then take the shuttle to Bear Lake Trailhead.

column1: You can also shorten the trip by simply going to lake helene and back (4.8 miles).
column2: You can also shorten the trip by simply going to Lake Helene and back (4.8 miles).

column1: Iconic in every way, longs peak is the pinnacle of rocky mountain national park and one of colorado’s classic climbs.
column2: Iconic in every way, Longs Peak is the pinnacle of Rocky Mountain National Park and one of Colorado’s classic climbs.

column1: The tallest peak in the park (14,259ft), longs peak can be summited on the exhilarating and exhausting keyhole route, which features on many visitors' to-do lists.
column2: The tallest peak in the park (14,259ft), Longs Peak can be summited on the exhilarating and exhausting Keyhole Route, which features on many visitors' to-do lists.

column1: chasm lake, located at the foot of the diamond – longs peak's legendary east face where technical climbers rope up to scale the 1000ft wall – is routinely rated as one of the park’s best hikes.
column2: Chasm Lake, located at the foot of the Diamond – Longs Peak's legendary east face where technical climbers rope up to scale the 1000ft wall – is routinely rated as one of the park’s best hikes.

column1: chasm lake features all the spectacular scenery of the peak without the risk and arduous ascent.
column2: Chasm Lake features all the spectacular scenery of the peak without the risk and arduous ascent.

column1: At the northeastern end of rocky mountain national park is lumpy ridge, composed of 1.8-billion-year-old granite formations that were sculpted by the elements rather than by glaciers.
column2: At the northeastern end of Rocky Mountain National Park is Lumpy Ridge, composed of 1.8-billion-year-old granite formations that were sculpted by the elements rather than by glaciers.

column1: The trail to gem lake is a great way to explore the area, with superb vistas back to the continental divide all the way up to the jewel-like lake.
column2: The trail to Gem Lake is a great way to explore the area, with superb vistas back to the Continental Divide all the way up to the jewel-like lake.

column1: One of the easier peaks to access along the continental divide, mount ida (12,880ft) is a choice spot to enjoy a prolonged top-of-the-world feeling and monumental views in all directions.
column2: One of the easier peaks to access along the Continental Divide, Mount Ida (12,880ft) is a choice spot to enjoy a prolonged top-of-the-world feeling and monumental views in all directions.

column1: Perhaps because it is on the western side of the park, mount ida is a relatively unknown summit and an excellent place to escape the crowds on the trail ridge road.
column2: Perhaps because it is on the western side of the park, Mount Ida is a relatively unknown summit and an excellent place to escape the crowds on the Trail Ridge Road.

column1: mount ida is a relatively gradual ascent, following the continental divide trail past miniature alpine wildflowers (whose roots extend 6 feet below ground) all the way to the summit.
column2: Mount Ida is a relatively gradual ascent, following the Continental Divide Trail past miniature alpine wildflowers (whose roots extend 6 feet below ground) all the way to the summit.

column1: With a nickname like the grand canyon state, you can bet that arizona boasts some incredible landscapes.
column2: With a nickname like the Grand Canyon State, you can bet that Arizona boasts some incredible landscapes.

column1: In addition to that crown jewel, it's also home to the tonto rim (which inspired Western writers like zane gray), palm canyon's rare stands of native trees, ancient lava flows, spectacular slickrock, and the brilliant turquoise of havasu falls.
column2: In addition to that crown jewel, it's also home to the Tonto Rim (which inspired Western writers like Zane Gray), Palm Canyon's rare stands of native trees, ancient lava flows, spectacular slickrock, and the brilliant turquoise of Havasu Falls.

column1: laced through all that rugged terrain are an array of trails for every hiker.
column2: Laced through all that rugged terrain are an array of trails for every hiker.

column1: From ada accessible loops with unbeatable views to truly challenging treks that test the hardiest of outdoor athletes, from desert switchbacks strewn with petroglyphs to urban jaunts you can tackle with a to-go coffee in hand, there's a little something for everyone.
column2: From ADA accessible loops with unbeatable views to truly challenging treks that test the hardiest of outdoor athletes, from desert switchbacks strewn with petroglyphs to urban jaunts you can tackle with a to-go coffee in hand, there's a little something for everyone.

column1: If you're wondering how to make the most of your time in the grand canyon state, these are the seventeen best hiking destinations in arizona.
column2: If you're wondering how to make the most of your time in the Grand Canyon State, these are the seventeen best hiking destinations in Arizona.

column1: The most popular and accessible of the grand canyon corridor trails is the beautiful bright angel trail, a spectacularly scenic 7.8-mile descent to the colorado river with several logical day-hike destinations.
column2: The most popular and accessible of the Grand Canyon corridor trails is the beautiful Bright Angel Trail, a spectacularly scenic 7.8-mile descent to the Colorado River with several logical day-hike destinations.

column1: summer heat can be crippling; day hikers should turn around at one of the two rest houses (3- or 6-mile round-trip) or hit the trail at dawn to safely make the longer hikes to Indian garden and plateau point (9- and 12-mile round-trip, respectively).
column2: Summer heat can be crippling; day hikers should turn around at one of the two rest houses (3- or 6-mile round-trip) or hit the trail at dawn to safely make the longer hikes to Indian Garden and Plateau Point (9- and 12-mile round-trip, respectively).

column1: Overnight hikers can secure a backcountry permit in advance to camp at Indian garden, about halfway down and one of the park's three developed inner-canyon campgrounds.
column2: Overnight hikers can secure a backcountry permit in advance to camp at Indian Garden, about halfway down and one of the park's three developed inner-canyon campgrounds.

column1: havasu creek tumbles through the grand canyon on its way to the colorado river, creating a series of waterfalls and swimming pools about 10 miles below the rim on the havasupai reservation.
column2: Havasu Creek tumbles through the Grand Canyon on its way to the Colorado River, creating a series of waterfalls and swimming pools about 10 miles below the rim on the Havasupai Reservation.

column1: The cathedral rock vortex is a spectacular location for watching red-rock sunsets.
column2: The Cathedral Rock vortex is a spectacular location for watching red-rock sunsets.

column1: The north rim's most accessible inner-canyon trek features strenuous switchbacks, raging waterfalls, a cottonwood-fringed campground and long creekside stretches.
column2: The North Rim's most accessible inner-canyon trek features strenuous switchbacks, raging waterfalls, a cottonwood-fringed campground and long creekside stretches.

column1: The fabulous natural formation known as tonto bridge was formed over countless centuries of attrition as pine creek scoured through a massive dam of calcium carbonate.
column2: The fabulous natural formation known as Tonto Bridge was formed over countless centuries of attrition as Pine Creek scoured through a massive dam of calcium carbonate.

column1: One of the best is the Pine creek trail, a strenuous one-mile loop with 229ft of elevation gain.
column2: One of the best is the Pine Creek Trail, a strenuous one-mile loop with 229ft of elevation gain.

column1: The crown jewel of grand canyon north rim backpacking is a hot, miserable trail connecting an embarrassment of waterfalls, swimming holes and slot canyons.
column2: The crown jewel of Grand Canyon North Rim backpacking is a hot, miserable trail connecting an embarrassment of waterfalls, swimming holes and slot canyons.

column1: By combining thunder river and tapeats creek trails with a 3-mile scramble along the colorado river to deer creek, you create an epic adventure that highlights everything we love about the grand canyon – including the profound suffering.
column2: By combining Thunder River and Tapeats Creek trails with a 3-mile scramble along the Colorado River to Deer Creek, you create an epic adventure that highlights everything we love about the Grand Canyon – including the profound suffering.

column1: This deservedly popular trail crosses oak creek a dozen times as it winds through the canyon, where walls soar more than 200ft in some places.
column2: This deservedly popular trail crosses Oak Creek a dozen times as it winds through the canyon, where walls soar more than 200ft in some places.

column1: It's located 9.5 miles north of sedona (a few miles north of slide rock state park) and 17.5 miles south of flagstaff on hwy 89A; look for the signed parking lot.
column2: It's located 9.5 miles north of Sedona (a few miles north of Slide Rock State Park) and 17.5 miles south of Flagstaff on Hwy 89A; look for the signed parking lot.

column1: This 2704ft twin-humped mountain sits smack in the center of the phoenix action.
column2: This 2704ft twin-humped mountain sits smack in the center of the Phoenix action.

column1: The two trails, the cholla trail (6131 e cholla lane) and the echo canyon trail (4925 e mcdonald dr), are short but steep, with 1264ft of elevation gain over a mere 1.2 miles and lots of hands-on scrambling over boulders.
column2: The two trails, the Cholla Trail (6131 E Cholla Lane) and the Echo Canyon Trail (4925 E McDonald Dr), are short but steep, with 1264ft of elevation gain over a mere 1.2 miles and lots of hands-on scrambling over boulders.

column1: Gorgeous boynton canyon includes shaded stretches, petroglyphs and sinagua ruins.
column2: Gorgeous Boynton Canyon includes shaded stretches, petroglyphs and Sinagua ruins.

column1: During the relatively easy 6-mile hike (round trip), look for the rock formation known as kachina woman and try not to be moved.
column2: During the relatively easy 6-mile hike (round trip), look for the rock formation known as Kachina Woman and try not to be moved.

column1: From sedona, head a couple of miles west on Highway 89A to dry creek rd; turn north and follow signs to boynton canyon and enchantment resort.
column2: From Sedona, head a couple of miles west on Highway 89A to Dry Creek Rd; turn north and follow signs to Boynton Canyon and Enchantment Resort.

column1: Meandering through shady forests of mixed conifer, old-growth ponderosa pine and quaking aspen punctuated by carpets of lupine, the widforss trail rolls past the head of The transept and out to widforss point.
column2: Meandering through shady forests of mixed conifer, old-growth ponderosa pine and quaking aspen punctuated by carpets of lupine, the Widforss Trail rolls past the head of The Transept and out to Widforss Point.

column1: numbered interpretive signs provide some depth to your stroll, while the dramatic viewpoint at the end provides an ideal place to have a picnic.

column1: The shortest is 0.9 miles to ooh aah point, a popular marked turnaround, but if you continue just a few minutes more, you'll find a fantastic wide and flat stone outcrop that makes a perfect spot to relax with a snack before tackling the return trek to the rim.

column1: known decades ago as welfare island, thanks to its assortment of hospitals, and before that as blackwell island, when it was home to an asylum, a prison, and even more hospitals, new york city’s roosevelt island hasn’t always been a popular attraction.

column1: But in recent years, this tiny island in the east river has become a quick, easy escape from the urban sprawl, boasting green spaces, historic landmarks, a chic new hotel with an even chicer rooftop bar, and an aerial tram with incredible views of manhattan’s upper east side.
column2: But in recent years, this tiny island in the East River has become a quick, easy escape from the urban sprawl, boasting green spaces, historic landmarks, a chic new hotel with an even chicer rooftop bar, and an aerial tram with incredible views of Manhattan’s Upper East Side.

column1: Giving the staten island ferry a run for its money as one of the best ways to see new york's sights without breaking the bank, the roosevelt island tram glides over upper east side avenues and the east river, offering one of the city's most memorable commutes – all for the swipe of a metrocard.

column1: Fortunately, it was eventually revived: Four freedoms state park opened in 2012, and it's a sight to behold, comprising an open-topped deck lined with tall granite blocks.

column1: (Its name is a reference to a line in The great gatsby, for all you bibliophiles.)

column2: Alaska is a storied landscape – just ask the Inupiat and Tlingit people, who have for generations shared tales about how the state's peninsulas and glaciers and crevasses were formed, and of the bears, whales, and ravens that fill Alaska's forests.

column1: And those same natural features continue to draw hikers from all over the world who want to experience alaska up close and personal, one mile at a time.
column2: And those same natural features continue to draw hikers from all over the world who want to experience Alaska up close and personal, one mile at a time.

column1: The chilkoot trail, the epic trek undertaken by over 30,000 gold-rush stampeders in 1897–8, is sometimes known as the "Last Great Adventure" or the "Meanest 33 miles in america."
column2: The Chilkoot Trail, the epic trek undertaken by over 30,000 gold-rush stampeders in 1897–8, is sometimes known as the "Last Great Adventure" or the "Meanest 33 Miles in America."

column1: Its appeal is legendary, and, consequently, more than 3000 people spend three to five days following the historic route between dyea (alaska) and bennett (british columbia, canada) every summer.
column2: Its appeal is legendary, and, consequently, more than 3000 people spend three to five days following the historic route between Dyea (Alaska) and Bennett (British Columbia, Canada) every summer.

column1: The trailhead is at dyea, 9 miles northwest of skagway and site of a once-rambunctious gold rush town that came and went in the space of just six years (1897–1903).
column2: The trailhead is at Dyea, 9 miles northwest of Skagway and site of a once-rambunctious gold rush town that came and went in the space of just six years (1897–1903).

column1: The hike ends at lake bennett in bc, canada, which has a good campground, a railway station and an unusual wooden church dating from 1898.
column2: The hike ends at Lake Bennett in BC, Canada, which has a good campground, a railway station and an unusual wooden church dating from 1898.

column1: A special "hiker’s train" using the historic white pass & yukon route railroad leaves lake bennett for skagway four times a week (3:15pm on tuesday, wednesday and thursday, and 2:15pm on saturday).
column2: A special "hiker’s train" using the historic White Pass & Yukon Route Railroad leaves Lake Bennett for Skagway four times a week (3:15pm on Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday, and 2:15pm on Saturday).

column1: Experiencing the chilkoot and returning on the train is probably the ultimate alaska trek, combining great scenery, a historical site and an incredible sense of adventure.
column2: Experiencing the Chilkoot and returning on the train is probably the ultimate Alaska trek, combining great scenery, a historical site and an incredible sense of adventure.

column1: Before starting the trail, all hikers must call in at the trail center in skagway to obtain backpacking permits (adult/child $55/27.45), check out trail conditions and watch a bear safety video.
column2: Before starting the trail, all hikers must call in at the Trail Center in Skagway to obtain backpacking permits (adult/child $55/27.45), check out trail conditions and watch a bear safety video.

column1: parks canada allows only 50 hikers per day on the trail and holds only eight permits to be handed out each day at the trail center.
column2: Parks Canada allows only 50 hikers per day on the trail and holds only eight permits to be handed out each day at the trail center.

column1: It is wise to reserve your permits ($11.70 per reservation) in advance through Parks canada if you intend to walk mid-July to mid-August.
column2: It is wise to reserve your permits ($11.70 per reservation) in advance through Parks Canada if you intend to walk mid-July to mid-August.

column1: don’t forget your passport.
column2: Don’t forget your passport.

column1: The national historic iditarod trail is a 24-mile trek used by gold miners and sled-dog teams until 1918 when the alaska railroad was finished.
column2: The National Historic Iditarod Trail is a 24-mile trek used by gold miners and sled-dog teams until 1918 when the Alaska Railroad was finished.

column1: It’s a two- to three-day hike through superb mountain scenery to girdwood (where it's known as the crow pass trail) and is the region’s best backpack adventure.
column2: It’s a two- to three-day hike through superb mountain scenery to Girdwood (where it's known as the Crow Pass Trail) and is the region’s best backpack adventure.

column1: pitch a tent at rapids camp or echo bend (mile 3), or rent one of two yurts ($65 per night) close by.
column2: Pitch a tent at Rapids Camp or Echo Bend (Mile 3), or rent one of two yurts ($65 per night) close by.

column1: For a shorter outing, you can turn around at the perch, a massive rock in the middle of wonderland, then backtrack to the dew mound trail at echo bend and loop back to the nature center, making this a scenic 8-mile trip.
column2: For a shorter outing, you can turn around at the Perch, a massive rock in the middle of wonderland, then backtrack to the Dew Mound Trail at Echo Bend and loop back to the Nature Center, making this a scenic 8-mile trip.

column1: Two alpine lakes, waterfalls, glaciers and towering granite walls: the 7-to-9-mile reed lakes trail is one of the most gorgeous hikes in the region and worth the climb.
column2: Two alpine lakes, waterfalls, glaciers and towering granite walls: the 7-to-9-mile Reed Lakes Trail is one of the most gorgeous hikes in the region and worth the climb.

column1: Once you reach upper reed lake, continue 1 mile to bomber glacier, where the ruin of a b-29 bomber lies in memorial to six men who perished in a 1957 crash.
column2: Once you reach upper Reed Lake, continue 1 mile to Bomber Glacier, where the ruin of a B-29 bomber lies in memorial to six men who perished in a 1957 crash.

column1: Near mile 14 of hatcher pass rd, a road to archangel valley splits off from fishhook–willow rd and leads to the reed lakes trailhead, a wide road.
column2: Near mile 14 of Hatcher Pass Rd, a road to Archangel Valley splits off from Fishhook–Willow Rd and leads to the Reed Lakes trailhead, a wide road.

column2: If you’ve got a 4WD, you can (theoretically) drive the first 3 miles of the Craigie Creek Trail.

column1: It then becomes a very steep trail for 3 miles to Dogsled pass, where you can access several wilderness trails into the talkeetna mountains.
column2: It then becomes a very steep trail for 3 miles to Dogsled Pass, where you can access several wilderness trails into the Talkeetna Mountains.

column1: This challenging 7-mile trail to an alpine lake is one of the most scenic hikes the kenai peninsula has to offer in midsummer.
column2: This challenging 7-mile trail to an alpine lake is one of the most scenic hikes the Kenai Peninsula has to offer in midsummer.

column1: The trailhead is in lost lake subdivision, at mile 5.3 of the seward hwy.
column2: The trailhead is in Lost Lake subdivision, at Mile 5.3 of the Seward Hwy.

column1: clemens memorial cabin is 4.5 miles up the trail (book way ahead).
column2: Clemens Memorial Cabin is 4.5 miles up the trail (book way ahead).

column1: It has amazing views of resurrection bay and is also a good winter destination.
column2: It has amazing views of Resurrection Bay and is also a good winter destination.

column1: The final 2 miles are above the treeline, making the shores of lost lake a wondrous place to pitch a tent.
column2: The final 2 miles are above the treeline, making the shores of Lost Lake a wondrous place to pitch a tent.

column2: Plan on seven to 10 hours for the round-trip to Lost Lake, and bring a camp stove, as wood is hard to come by.

column2: Exit Glacier Guides gives you the chance to tread upon Seward’s backyard glacier.

column2: Its six-hour ice-hiking trip costs $130 per person, gears you up with crampons and ropes, ascends partway up the Harding Ice Field Trail and then heads out onto the glacier for crevasse exploration and interpretive glaciology.

column2: Exit Glacier Guides also offers helicopter tours, hiking tours and a historic downtown tour as well as overnight journeys.

column2: The first stretch winds around reedy Hartney Bay, followed by a mellow 2-mile climb to the tree line through forests and wildflowers (and, in rainy weather, lots of mud – rubber boots are recommended).

column1: This 16-mile trail accesses a 72-mile trail system connecting seward and hope.
column2: This 16-mile trail accesses a 72-mile trail system connecting Seward and Hope.

column2: Resurrection River Cabin is 7 miles from the trailhead and cannot be reserved.

column1: The southern trailhead is at mile 8 of exit glacier rd.

column2: The northern trailhead joins the Russian Lakes Trail 5 miles from Cooper Lake or 16 miles from the Russian River Campground off the Sterling Hwy.

column2: The hike from the Seward Hwy to the Sterling Hwy is a 40-mile trip, including Exit Glacier.

column2: On the southeast side of Unalaska, this pleasant hike is 2.2 miles one-way along an ancient portage route.

column2: This 5-mile loop starts at the end of Monashka Bay Rd and branches into several trails near Termination Point, a spectacular peninsula that juts out into Narrow Strait.

column1: Most hiking is done in a lush sitka spruce forest.
column2: Most hiking is done in a lush Sitka spruce forest.

column1: riverbeds are easy to follow and make excellent avenues for the backpacker.
column2: Riverbeds are easy to follow and make excellent avenues for the backpacker.

column2: The trek is well worth it for those with the stamina, as it provides spectacular views of not only the ice field but Exit Glacier and the valley below.

column1: The perseverance trail, off basin rd, is juneau’s most popular.

column2: The trail is a path into Juneau’s mining history and also provides access to two other popular treks: Mt Juneau Trail and Granite Creek Trail.

column2: Together the routes can be combined into a rugged 10-hour walk for hardy hikers or an overnight excursion into the mountains surrounding Alaska’s capital city.

column1: To reach perseverance trail, head north out of town on basin rd, a dirt road that curves away from the city into the mountains as it follows gold creek.
column2: To reach Perseverance Trail, head north out of town on Basin Rd, a dirt road that curves away from the city into the mountains as it follows Gold Creek.

column2: The trailhead is at the road’s end, at the parking lot for Last Chance Mining Museum.

column2: From the Perseverance Trail, you can pick up Granite Creek Trail and follow it to the creek’s headwaters basin, a beautiful spot to spend the night.

column1: From there, you can reach mt juneau by climbing the ridge and staying left of mt olds, the huge rocky mountain.
column2: From there, you can reach Mt Juneau by climbing the ridge and staying left of Mt Olds, the huge rocky mountain.

column2: Once atop Mt Juneau, you can complete the loop by descending along the Mt Juneau Trail, which joins Perseverance Trail a mile from its beginning.

column1: From the trailhead for the perseverance trail to the upper basin of granite creek is 33 miles one way.
column2: From the trailhead for the Perseverance Trail to the upper basin of Granite Creek is 33 miles one way.

column2: Located in Arches National Park, you've seen this arch before: it's the unofficial state symbol, stamping nearly every Utah tourist brochure and prominently depicted on license plates.

column1: park near wolfe ranch, a well-preserved 1908 pioneer cabin.

column2: From there, a footbridge crosses Salt Wash (near American Indian rock art) and marks the beginning of the trail to the arch itself.

column2: Among the world’s longest natural stone spans in Arches National Park, Landscape Arch is a spectacular ribbon of rock reached via a moderate gravel trail with spurs of interest.

column1: landscape arch lies 0.8 miles along the devils garden trail at the northern end of the main park road.
column2: Landscape Arch lies 0.8 miles along the Devils Garden trail at the northern end of the main park road.

column1: Along the route, don’t miss the short spurs (0.5 miles) to tunnel and pine tree arches.
column2: Along the route, don’t miss the short spurs (0.5 miles) to Tunnel and Pine Tree Arches.

column2: A third of a mile in, bear right at the fork and head downhill to Tunnel Arch (on your right) and the 45ft Pine Tree Arch (on your left).

column1: High on a cliff, aptly named tunnel arch looks like a subway tube through the entrada sandstone.

column2: Look for the gnarled namesake juniper, which juts from the base of the window.

column2: As you approach Landscape Arch along the main trail, the terrain opens up, revealing long views to distant ridges and a vast expanse of sky.

column1: When you notice the cracks on the left side of the arch, it’s easy to understand why the national parks service (nps) closed the trail.

column2: Park at the Elephant Hill trailhead, three miles from Squaw Flat Campground.

column2: Cross the wash at the T-junction and follow signs to Chesler Park (not Druid Arch), descending 300ft along switchbacks into Elephant Canyon.

column1: continue to follow signs along the canyon floor.
column2: Continue to follow signs along the canyon floor.

column1: The final 0.2 miles to the chesler park viewpoint climbs 100ft, topping out on the rocky pass amid spires 2.9 miles from the trailhead.
column2: The final 0.2 miles to the Chesler Park Viewpoint climbs 100ft, topping out on the rocky pass amid spires 2.9 miles from the trailhead.

column1: This marks the beginning of the 5-mile chesler park loop.
column2: This marks the beginning of the 5-mile Chesler Park Loop.

column2: Capitol Reef National Park’s most dramatic canyon is worth visiting just to walk between the sheer walls of the Narrows.

column2: The canyon’s walls inch closer and closer together until, about 1.25 miles from the trailhead, you reach the Narrows, where the 80-story canyon is just 15ft wide – a thrilling sight.

column2: The canyon walls shrink and spread out again as the flat trail approaches Hwy 24.

column1: The sandy track at the grand staircase-escalante national monument eventually follows a year-round running creek through a spectacular canyon before arriving at a 126ft waterfall, a joy on a hot day.
column2: The sandy track at the Grand Staircase-Escalante National Monument eventually follows a year-round running creek through a spectacular canyon before arriving at a 126ft waterfall, a joy on a hot day.
